website_summaries.verdict: This well-made sharpening stone by Norton can sharpen almost any blade, and is crafted to last – an affordable option for serious sharpening, but not ideal for producing a refined finish.
pros: An affordable sharpening stone by a top brand
Can sharpen most blades and even smooth out imperfections, thanks to the the dual 100/320 grit
cons: Requires oil, but it comes pre-oiled and ready to use

customer_reviews.title: Good for machinery
customer_reviews.text: Bought this to clean up nicks and burrs on machinery. Just used it for cleaning up a 9x42 milling machine table. The previous owners did not appear to be careful about maintaining the table as there were a lot of nicks and dropped tool marks. I coated the table with wd40 and gently ran the stone across the table and was able to clean all of them up.
customer_reviews.author: Seanano

customer_reviews.title: It Came Used
customer_reviews.text: Stone came used when I ordered new. Not happy. Had to spend a while getting the stupid swarf that was ingrained in the stone out. Other than that, good stone. Came flat, sharpens my knifes, does all that a stone should.
customer_reviews.author: Amanda G. Lyons

customer_reviews.title: I like this
customer_reviews.text: Sharp kitchen knives are important to me. These stones allow me to keep my cutlery in good shape with minimal effort. Only wish the manufacturer would mark the grit level on the stones or the box for clarity.
customer_reviews.author: Da Grump

customer_reviews.title: Not flat
customer_reviews.text: It claims to be flat but it's not. Fortunately, if I buy two more I can make a flat one... I do struggle to appreciate that mode of creating repeat business.
customer_reviews.author: M-W

customer_reviews.title: A classic stone for a perfect edge. I also use it to remove any ...
customer_reviews.text: A classic stone for a perfect edge. I also use it to remove any burrs on my machines ground surfaces. I am very pleased with this purchase. The packaging worked so it arrived in good condition.
customer_reviews.author: Stephen Brown

customer_reviews.title: Good working Stones
customer_reviews.text: Great stones for using around the shop. Nice and flat, work great.
customer_reviews.author: The guy with no plan

customer_reviews.title: a great sharpening system
customer_reviews.text: you can't beat a good stone and strap. the strap has compound embedded for a fine edge. this is a good company and the products are well made.
customer_reviews.author: David

customer_reviews.title: The proper material.
customer_reviews.text: I have been trying to find a proper sharpening stone for several years since my best stone went missing. Finally I can get a good edge on my blades.This stone rocks!
customer_reviews.author: Old School Mechanic

customer_reviews.title: ... practice to learn how to use the stone but enjoy cooking with sharp knives
customer_reviews.text: Took me a little practice to learn how to use the stone but enjoy cooking with sharp knives!
customer_reviews.author: glorlog

customer_reviews.title: Very nice.
customer_reviews.text: Very nice. Just recommend taking some very fine bead blast bead and surfacing it on a flat piece of steel with some oil or solvent. Then this really becomes even smoother.
customer_reviews.author: Andy

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: just what I was looking for, levels mating surfaces such as engine cases. Very fast shipping
customer_reviews.author: Billy Burt

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: awesome sharpening stone for my pocket knives as well as my wood working tools
customer_reviews.author: Justin

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Great stone for breaking edges off of surface ground materials, and sharpens lathe tools and knives very nicely!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: It's a gritty stick.
customer_reviews.text: The best scrape stone I've ever used. (Well, the second anyway.)
customer_reviews.author: B. Kennedy

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Love this stone! Perfect for on the go machine repair!
customer_reviews.author: Rooster Jackson

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for what I need
customer_reviews.text: On time and as advertised. Perfect for what I need.
customer_reviews.author: Kendall Chaffee

customer_reviews.title: Good buy
customer_reviews.text: Far superior to the water stone I purchased. Works great.
customer_reviews.author: Last Trade

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Nice flat, free cutting stone. I use it to sharpen lathe bits and machine scrapers.
customer_reviews.author: Larry

customer_reviews.title: Good stone
customer_reviews.text: I love this stone it works well for the knives I own. I would recommend this to a friend or anyone
customer_reviews.author: W. Doyle

customer_reviews.title: Very nice combo stone for the price
customer_reviews.text: I use this as a first step in my sharpening ritual. The coarse side Gets a good amount of material off for minor reshaping, while the finer side gets the sharpening going and prepares the blades well for the next step with shapton 1000 grit, followed by shapton 6000 grit.
customer_reviews.author: Biglou

customer_reviews.title: A very good man made stone
customer_reviews.text: It's a great stone for general shop use. However, it's very prone to becoming packed with material when stoning aluminum. I keep mine in a Tupperware container half full of mineral spirits to keep it lubricated.
customer_reviews.author: Alex

customer_reviews.title: In most of the factories in which I have worked ...
customer_reviews.text: In most of the factories in which I have worked use this exact stone. There is a reason why. The coarse side is effective without being too coarse and the India oilstone on the other side is an India oilstone enough said. Both sides do their job without producing grit. I have other stones because I sort of have a thing for them but this one is the only one I truly need.
customer_reviews.author: Christopher Purvis

customer_reviews.title: Good stone. Flat stones precision surfaces well
customer_reviews.text: Good stone. Flat stones precision surfaces well. Best for large surfaces like machine work tables. Not meant for small jobs.
customer_reviews.author: Joe S

customer_reviews.title: 5 stars
customer_reviews.text: Product was received on time and exactly as described. I would recommend this to anyone interested:)
customer_reviews.author: ManMed

customer_reviews.title: Not sure how to rate this.
customer_reviews.text: The stone itself is great. The description says that the original item was $151.- due to it being in a special anniversary box. I envisioned some sort of wooden box because these stones were in a wooden box many years ago. The stone I received was in a simple cardboard box with a pretty picture on it. Not exactly what I was hoping for.
customer_reviews.author: J. R. Smith - Upland, Ca.

customer_reviews.title: I should of gotten the 8 inch there both made ...
customer_reviews.text: I should of gotten the 8 inch there both made in Mexico sadly get their oil I use it out Kurt vise and Haas VF1 TABLE seems small I will get the 8 inch later
customer_reviews.author: Frank Rivera

customer_reviews.title: Overall good stone
customer_reviews.text: Overall a nice stone and came in a nice cardboard box. I’m taking off a star because the different sides of the stone are not marked in any way as to coarseness. The difference between the two is so close I’m not sure I’m using the finer side
customer_reviews.author: Gerald Widen

customer_reviews.title: Great product
customer_reviews.text: Used this to stone internal parts of a Contender as the action was stiff and hard to open. A few passes with this stone and there was immediate improvement. My father is 75 and was having a hard time opening the handgun. This was just the ticket to making it smoother for him. Sits with my gun workbench among the tools. Would buy again.
customer_reviews.author: Todd

customer_reviews.title: Amazing stone for sharpening large blades
customer_reviews.text: I have 3 1” by 6” stones that work well up to 9” blades, but sharpening my machete is just impossible on those small stones. However, this sharpening stone does the job well and fast.
customer_reviews.author: Jessie Alfaro

customer_reviews.title: Take care of the stone and it will take care of your knives.
customer_reviews.text: A great stone for sharpening. I have a few stones this one is my best one and go too.
customer_reviews.author: Dave

customer_reviews.title: a great stone
customer_reviews.text: A great stone for the money. Was able to sharpen 2 knives in no time. It is aggressive so be careful with the angles but I really like it
customer_reviews.author: NecroKhaos

customer_reviews.title: Machinist approved
customer_reviews.text: Norton are the only stones I buy. So easy to clean with wd-40, and super solid for surface finish.
customer_reviews.author: invertedcheeses

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Stone
customer_reviews.text: This stone work very well if you follow the instructions.
customer_reviews.author: Roaddawg52

customer_reviews.title: exceptionally nice sharpening stone.
customer_reviews.text: I found this norton stone fast and easy to use. It is cleaner and more versatile than my water stones.
customer_reviews.author: paul

customer_reviews.title: Quality Stone
customer_reviews.text: This Norton stone works better than any Arkansas stone that I have used. The coarse cuts fast to create an edge, and the fine leaves a very clean and sharp edge that will cut well. Finish with a leather strop, and you will have a shaver.
customer_reviews.author: Casey Brown

customer_reviews.title: Great stone for large surfaces
customer_reviews.text: I use this in a manufacturing setting. These stones are great for removing high spots off die plates, burrs form reference surfaces without affecting the surface.
customer_reviews.author: Miles Heather

customer_reviews.title: Works as expected
customer_reviews.text: Perfect for sharpening my Chisels. I use Simple green for the lubricant, rather than oil.
customer_reviews.author: TattoodBrew

customer_reviews.title: Works great
customer_reviews.text: Works very well for setting initial edge to produce a razor edge with arkansas stone.
customer_reviews.author: Matt M

customer_reviews.title: Great stone but try a different oil for better results
customer_reviews.text: These stones are great but I learned that really the secret it to use the correct oil for the stone. All of the oil sold has way too much oil in it. Think about it, oil lubricates and prevents friction, something you don't want when sharpening. Make your own oil by mixing mineral oil and paint thinner. The oil to thinner ratio is around 1 to 10. You know you have it right when you rub some between your fingers and it's not very slippery. Make sure to constantly clean the stone with new oil because you will now be removing a lot more material.
customer_reviews.author: SN

customer_reviews.title: Disappointed
customer_reviews.text: Sent me the wrong stone twice....the picture does not match the product
customer_reviews.author: Theresa

product_meta.title: Norton Combination Grit Abrasive Benchstone, Aluminum Oxide, 6" Length x 2" Width x 1" Height
product_meta.description:
The Norton 100/320-grit combination oilstone is made of aluminum oxide with 100 grit on one face for repairing steel cutting edges and 320 grit on the opposite face for sharpening and maintaining them; it produces durable, smooth-cutting edges, and is preferred for close tolerances. The stone is prefilled with oil to save time and eliminate the need to presoak it prior to use. The oil prevents metal from bonding with the abrasive surface by flushing away dislodged abrasive and metal chips. This oilstone is commonly used to restore cutting edges on small straight-edged tools such as chisels, knives, plane blades, and precision instruments. 

This aluminum oxide stone has a tough fracture- and wear-resistant grit that is more durable than silicon carbide and capable of sharpening to very close tolerances. It is created by grading aluminum oxide to a consistent particle size and blending it with bonding agents. It is then molded and surface-finished. This 1 x 6 x 2 inch (H x W x D) stone, suitable for bench use, is harder and more durable than a waterstone. (H is height, the vertical distance from lowest to highest point; W is width, the horizontal distance from left to right; D is depth, the horizontal distance from front to back.) It conforms to the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) abrasive grit standards.

Sharpening stones, or whetstones, are abrasive surfaces used to sharpen and hone the edges of steel cutting implements, such as chisels, knives, scissors, hand scrapers, and plane blades. Sharpening is the process of creating or re-establishing a cutting edge by grinding away portions of the metal to adjust the angle of the edge and reform the shape. Honing removes small imperfections. Stones can be flat, for working flat edges, or shaped, for edges that are more complex. Sharpening stones are made of natural or synthetic materials that range from softer to harder, and are categorized by the size of their abrasive particles, known as grit. A stone with a coarser grit is used when more metal needs to be removed (e.g., when sharpening a nicked or very dull blade); the stone with the finest grit produces the sharpest edge. Where numbers are assigned to specify grit, they range from coarser grit (low) to finer grit (high). Some sharpening stones are designed for use with a lubricating liquid, some can be used dry, and others can be used either wet or dry. When used with lubricating liquid, a sharpening stone can be called a waterstone or an oilstone, based on the lubricant required.

Norton Abrasives manufactures sanding, grinding, and polishing abrasives, and has been located in the United States since 1885. Norton, now a brand of Saint-Gobain, meets ISO 9000 and 14001 certification for quality and environmental management standards.
feature_bullets: Specification: India, coarse/fine with anniversary box^Better performance level
